sourceDesc.p: Transcribed directly from photography of Venetus A MS

div.p: Aristarchus writes Αἱσύμνηθεν as does the text of Zenodtus and the text of Aristophanes.
The texts of Aristarchus have it this way τραπε with the alpha.
Zenodotus, Aristophanes, and those who agree with them [write] ἵππω.
The lines were not in Zendotous.

Since heaven has three distinct parts: the lower air spans up until the clouds, then the aether spans up until the visible places. In a similar way so it goes both from earth to Hades and from Hades to Tartarus, Tartarus is in opposition to Olympus. For the one, “never shook with winds, nor with heavy rain” (Odyssey 6.43). And the other seemed to be both chaotic and cold, indeed they say that to fall into Tartarus is to be violently cold. The former is wholly shone upon. The latter is murky.
This is the arrangement of the cosmos according to Homer. And because nothing like this is said about Olympus, and because he leaves out υπερθεν, which means as far as it is above.

The shadowy place below the earth, it is the bottommost portion of Hades. And he says that it lies in the deepest region or that it is difficult and vexatious. And it is so named because of the drawing out and the confounding of everything in itself. But others understand it as the unlit region of their inhabitance
All the way down to Hades:

He says that Tartarus stands as far from Hades as Ouranus is from the earth. And through these [references] he makes the cosmos spherical; he has introduced the earth in the relation of the center [of the cosmos], he says that [going] straight from the earth to each opposite side is equidistant.

It means many things. On the one hand it is the part of day that has that time. One the other hand it is the embodiment of a deity as it is in "Dawn from her couch, next to noble Tithonos" (Iliad 11.1). The time from sunrise until midday is the interval just as in "Twelve dawns have already passed for me in Ilium" (Iliad 21.80-21.81).

The epithet is for the retreat. 1. He is a farmer "in the grass, a curved scythe" (Odyssey 18.368) 2. A steersman "for [I] always [steered] the sails of the ship" (Odyssey 10.32) 3. A carpenter from the bed (cf. Odyssey 23.189) 4. A ship builder, from the raft (cf. Odyssey 5.243-5.261) 5. A hunter, from [the hunt] at Parnassos (c.f. Odyssey 19.428-19.454) 6. A seer, "I say let someone speak to me" (Odyssey 20.100) Allen’s OCT edition of the Odyssey reads φήμην τίς μοι φάσθω on this line instead of φημι τίς μοι φάσθω, which would make it “let someone utter an omen to me” 7. A cook "cutting up and roasting" (Odyssey 15.323) 8. A doctor "so that he might have to rub on his arrows" (Odyssey 1.262-263) 9. A musician "a speech like a singer" (Odyssey 11.368) 10. A boxer "in boxing I overcame Klytomedes" (Iliad 23.634) 11. A wrestler "in wrestling [I beat] Ancaeus of Pleuron" (Iliad 23.635) 12. A discus thrower against the Phaiacians (cf. Odyssey 8.186-8.198) 13. An archer "I know the bow well" (Odyssey 8.215) 14. A javelin-thrower "throwing a spear" (Odyssey 8.229) 15. An orator and an astronomer "looking upon the Pleiades" (Odyssey 5.272)”

the sign is there because it is in the subjunctive. "Neither to retreat nor to fight the enemy." But that is not so. For he was "of two minds." It was not that he was worried about two different things, but that we interpret it the same "to turn his horses and fight."
It is symbolic of Nestor himself. For some say that his arms were wrought by Hephaestus.

The bars with which one strengthens shields, for when they are attached to the handle of a shield, which they call οχανα. For later these men had thought it came from the Carians because Anacreon wrote "Carian-made shield bars."
The sign is there because the arms are wrought by Hephaestus because he took them from Glaukos and he handed out from the arms to his men, and it is not in figurative language.

There is an acute accent on the syllable ανθ because it is the full form αντα as Demetrios of Gonypesus correctly thought. And on my part, this way of literary interpretation is acceptable. For clearly each man says that he would make a stand against 100 or even 200 Trojans. For the syntax of αντα is not delayed, unless it takes the genitive.

there is no critical sign on this lineThe sign is also there because απο ταφρου πυργος εεργε is written in some sources. εκ νεων can be connected with απο ταφρου because either πυργος (tower) or ταφρος (trench) can be against the ships. And it is possible the things said between the wall the wall and trench, the most of horses and men are between the wall and the trench, and when he says εκ νεων so that it it indicates the space is left between the wall and the trench according to the topography of newly built things/

The sign is there because αυερυοντα is clearly means drawing backwards if it's οπισω, there are some issues in interpreting the words in the Byzantinue orthography and "a bow that's curved back" comes from this. One must not entirely make a distinction for αυερυοντα as Neoteles thinks. For ωμον agrees with him [Teucer] both being hit and drawing. Indeed, Neoteles of Scythia claims that archery is drawing the bow to the shoulder.

The sign is there because while everyone turned around, Odysseus alone remained next to the ships with the result that the above line is in good order "as he spoke he did not listen" (Iliad 8.97) because he voluntarily sent himself past
Heracles: this lemma is not actually from the line

Heracles laid waste to windy Ilium and he took captive the daughter of Laomedon and sister of Priam and gave her as a gift to Telemon since he joined him on the expedition. From her, Telamon had Teucer. Since he brought into the world by a Trojan woman, he called the child Teucer, moving the accent back and making it a proper noun. For the Trojans were called the Teucrians from their king Teucer. The story is more precisely told by many others and by Apollonius the grammarian in the second generation. It is asked how having received praise from everyone Teucer is now a bastard. We say that it was not a cause for dishonor. Because the custom of the ancients prevails. For they honored bastards equally with legitimate children. And otherwise if someone was a spearman or a commoner but also a royal. And on account of the magnification, we say that this is said for excellence that he surpasses the legitimate children.

The sign is there because if Olympus was not taken to be the mountain in Macedon, it would not agree with these things. For he [the poet] says that the drops of heaven draw Olympus up to a point so that a point may be bound up form the peak and the sign is also there because the εξ is superfluous.
the gates are strongly bound together and closed because nothing returns from Hades.
bringing forth from Erebus the hound of loathed Hades:

The sign is there because he makes mention of only this Labor [of Herakles], there are some according to legend. And because he calls him only κυνα and does not call him Cerberus as the newer [poets] do. From the the greatest labor, he makes clear all of the labors. They know the hound or the form of him. Pindar says he has 100 heads. And Hesiod says he had 50 heads.
φρασσάμενοι (pointing out) is written, but rather αγασσαμενοι (wondering), is more in accordance with what follows.

Heraclides of Meilesius writes it with a grave accent/without an accent could mean either, like ἄσητα, and he uses this word as though it is a stronger βληξχρον, it ought to mean "not weak" like ακακος means “not evil", but it means ἀσθενές (without strength). Indeed the grammatical tradition marks it with an acute accent. ἀβληχρὰ and ἀβληχρὴν prevailed first by declining as if it is uncompounded. For thus they are declined like πενιχρα and ψυχρα. And I write in the feminine just like ἀβληχρά not sharing in whichever gender. And I write ὁ αβληχρὸς and ἡ ἀβληχρος. Elsewhere already this means βληχρὸς. Since after the majority rather [the meaning] ασθενες (without strength) Alcaeus 8 βληχρῶν ἀνέμων ἀχείμαντοι πνοαί "not stormy blasts of weak wind." And Nicandros writes βληχρὸν γὰρ μυὸς οἷα μυληβόρου ἐν χροῒ νύγμα "for the weakness of the mouse was a sort of millstone-eating, like pricking on the skin." Indeed adding the alpha to it keeps the accent in the same place. Because I know that the accent is always the same in ἄβορος ἄγαυρος and ἄσταχυς.
The sign is there because Zendotos writes ἄας δη καὶ μᾶλλον instead of ἐσαύριον but the word is not Homeric
αξεσαι is not the common form with σιτου, because inanimate objects do not use the verb αγω, rather φερεται. Therefore φερεται must be understood as left out.

This is the appropriate line order in my opinion ἠ εμοὶ ὅς πέρ οἱ θαλερὸς πόσις εὔχομαι εἶναι then οἴνον τ' ἐγκεράσασα πιεῖν ὅτε μοι θυμὸς ἀνώγοι but one must see that before being able to make use of the drinking cups they mix the drink
For she is always given to hinder me in whatever I have decreed:

ἐνικλᾶν means "to hinder." It is a metaphor from spears clashing against shields. And it must be written like so: ὅττι κεν εἴπω only to hinder and not to permit what is said by me. Again it is later written in the lines [that] Iris says ὅττι κεν εἴπῃ (Iliad 8.422)

The two lines are athetized. because the poet says nothing in the following line. And he substitutes/uses the relative pronoun ὃς μὲν instead of the definite article ὁ μέν. But the intention is of this sort concerning the things now and today, the reason is of service to me and nothing is omitted and nothing is omitted concerning the things happening tomorrow which under dawn I reveal.
The sign is there because in general he [the poet] does not say εὑρεῖαν, but in my opinion the earth becomes εὑρεῖα before he would compose εὐρὺ χάσμα
Some make a distinction after the φεύγοντι, but let us also join the whole line. We know that a man's back does not flee.
giving a sign to the Trojans:
One ought to have some short pause after Τρώεσσιν. Because the sign itself indicates the signal for the subsequent victory. But if we join it together, it is incorrect syntax.
The sign is there because Zenodotus left out Ἀρχεπτόλεμον and had composed above Ἰ̈φιτίδην Ερασιπτόλεμον
Xanthus and you Podargus and Aethon and goodly Lampus:

The sign is there because nowhere else does Homer show the use of four horses yoked together. And it is also a discrepancy with the two being brought forward and the simple address. There ought to be a short stop after each name, but if the cold one is joined, it is not able to be understood, because there are two epithets and two proper names, when the conjunctions joined by juxtaposition separate themselves from each other, but the proper names are never joined to the epithets.

But if it lay out of the full line, nothing would be questioned, but since it is understood the nu in the next line and is carried over by the grammarians, two rational follow. One because a period has fallen in the middle of the syllable ναυ and it possesses an interval of time, just like in the following: ὡς ἔφαθ' αι δ' ἐπέμυξαν (Iliad 4.20). ὡς εφαθ’ οὐδ' ἀπίθησεν (Iliad 2.166). The other reason is because it comes together at the beginning of the line after only the letter nu there is an interval of punctuation.
all the way from the ships:

There ought to be a short pause after the νηων, because it makes the idea expressed in ὅσον more clear. The trench is set away from the walls and the ships, the multitude was composed of footsoldiers and horses, leaving out the conjunction και. Because the ἔεργεν indicates a separation between the ships and the walls. The empty space in between was for a passage way. The space was broad and wide in the beginning, and long through the whole stream to the end. But again in this way, outside of the walls there was a short gap, after which the trench was dug which that gap was of such a size of one missile and the things on it are thrown from the ones attacking it. Indeed there were spaces on each side of the walls: One filled up the space before the trench, and the other before the ships. Nicanor says likewise.

The sign is there because πανομφαιος (diviner) ὁ κληδωνιος (receiver of omens) and πάσης κληδῶνος παραίτιος (the causer of all received omens) are not generally an epithet and because the epithet here is a hapax.
There ought to be a short pause after παπτηνας. But it ought to be punctuated on the corresponding/answering βεβληκει.

The two lines are athetized because it is not necessary to describe in detail piece by piece the things to the one who already knows it well. And indeed we do not narrate further something superfluous.

Like ανδρικως Aristarchus pronounces it with a circumflex, but it is said by us, regarding pronunciation, because we make a distinction regarding the [the use of the word in] ῆ δὴ λοίγια ἔργα τάδ' ἔσσεται οὐκέτ' ἀνεκτά (Iliad 1.573)

The three are athetized because during the aristea of Diomedes it is well brought out to completion. Because she does something. But here for no reason she puts on her armor. But Aristophanes also athetizes them, and Zenodotus does not write them.
There ought to be a short pause after the προς ενώπια so that the chariots are brightly shining. but one must see that ἅρματα means the chariots (οχηματα).

After it is formed thence it is accented with a grave. Since each accusative singular ending in alpha is accented with a grave with something unmodified having been removed, because of the well-ordered double nature and things of this sort. But below he is covering and concealing with a simple cover.

Whenever he [the poet] is looking at the reputation of the gods, then he says they would not be moved by anything concerning mortals. Just as we would not be moved concerning ants. But whenever he considers poetry, he follows the stories and makes the subject famous: bringing about alliances and wars among gods.

The two lines are athetized because through ἥματι τῷ it indicates a postponement of more time, but in the following lines, he brings forward Achilles to the ditch and he stands up to argue precisely not when he will stand up for some most opportune moment. But he holds off "until the swift footed son of Peleus is risen up next to the ships" (Il. 8.474). And he holds some imposed falsehood, not because they fight in great distress. But he is accustomed to say στείνει for a narrow road. But it is called a confined space by most people. But he says αινωτατω for a place that is difficult because of fear.

The sign is there because Zenodotus rejects from these lines down to the following four, because they are both written in another place. But Aristarchus says that they remain more appropriately here because of the discussion in the expedition.

The sign is there because Zenodotus writes ἔλπομαι εὐχόμενος. He does not say Hector is lifted up thusly, I feel hope praying to the gods. Because the opposite is suitable and appropriate, "I pray, feeling hope." I speak aloud being made hopeful by Zeus and the other gods.

The sign is there because it is necessary to keep these three lines, on which he places an anti sigma. Or the following three, on which the stigma are placed. Because they explain what the meaning is. But Aristarchus rather accepts as genuine the second three because the words are more loudly boastful. But Zenodotus accepts as genuine the first three and he does not write the second three. But regarding these lines Didymus says the same things, as does Aristonicus, for which reasons we did not write the things of Didymus.
So he spoke, but he did not hear/listen:
Regarding the ambiguity, whether he [Odysseus] did not generally perceive his [Diomedes’] voice on account of clamor, or having heard him he passed along, which is how Aristarchus takes it.
οὐδὲ ἤκουσεν It is interpreted whether he [Odysseus] generally did perceive his [Diomedes’] voice on account of clamor, or having heard him he passed along, which is how Aristarchus takes it

οὐδὲ ἤκουσεν It is interpreted whether Odysseus did not wholly hear, or whether he was not persuaded. They charge the hero with cowardice, ignoring the οὐδ’ ἐσάκουσεν. For it is not “not listening.” But rather it is a lack of perfect perception, and because he is not a coward since he flees last of all the other men and because of his slowness he is a specimen of a man who loves danger.
The trench encloses the space all the way from the ships to the tower:

The Aristarcheans have it two ways: ἔεργε and ἔρυκε. And it on both sides indicated is such of the Achaeans, the trench divides all the way from the wall and is full equally with horses and men driven together and shut in together by Hector. Zenodotus writes The scribe has accidentally repeated a large portion of the text. The repeated text has been left out of the translation for clarity. τῶν δ’ ὅσων ἐν νηῶν καὶ πύργου (all the way to the ships and the tower). But some say that the two spaces are full of Greeks and from the ships until the wall and from the wall until the ditch, which indeed he calls a narrow space (στεῖνος).
Having the eyes of the Gorgon:

Zenodotus writes Γοργονος ὄμματ’ ἔχων ἠὲ βροτολοιγοῦ Ἄρηος but Homer writes it without the nu τῇ δ ἐπο μὲν Γοργῷ (Il. 11.36) like Σαπφώ. On which account he writes Γοργοῦς like Σαπφοῦς. But Aristarchus writes it with the iota οἴμματ’ ἔχων and they say beside the path they become roads and impulses. However, most texts have the demotic version: Γοργοῦς ὅμματ’ ἔχων which should be understood also with what is said elsewhere namely: τῇ δ’ ἐπι μὲν Γοργος βλωσυρωτης (Il. 11.36) Indeed it is difficult to say something certain.

Aristarchus has προφανέντες similar to πληγέντε κεραυνῷ in the dual. But Zenodotus has γηθήσει προφανεῖσας ἰδὼν ἐς δοῦπον ἀκόντων contracting the ending with an acute accent on the penult pronouncing with the alpha extended. And it is pure Dorian and a rarity in something of this sort in the works of the poet.

They say that Aristarchus would be less reproachful [of this line], if indeed it had been written as follows: Εκτορος ὃ δὴ κῦδος Ὀλύμπιος αὐτὸς ὀπάζει. But it has been athetized also in the text of Aristophanes.
From that moment waiting with bows:

Thus the Aristarcheans have δεδεγμένος with a gamma. The Herodians have δεδεχμένος with a chi. And Diogenes says in the commentaries, that he writes εἰρωνευόμενος something like δεξιούμενος τοῖς τόξοις. Because δεδέχεσθαι is to welcome not without charm or explanation.

Chrysippus pronounces it as one word. Yet Aristarchus has it as two parts of speech and accents it with a circumflex on the penult. Indeed he writes it elsewhere as χρύσειοι δ’ ἄρα κοῦροι ἐϋδμήτων ἐπι βωμῶν (Od. 7.100). Indeed it is necessary to recognize that it is written with a mu. As it is similarly separated into two words in ἀμ φόνον ᾶν νέκυας (Il. 10.298). And the reason is explained in the Treatises Regarding Orthography (2.408.20).
But so that some certain missile:

The sign is there because he said the weapon to indicate the wound, it being a homonym for wounding. The texts of Aristophanes have πέσσοι. And Parmeniscus in Book One of Regarding Dominance, like the Aristarchean text, has ἀλλ ὥς τις κείνων γε

Aristarchus read it well as a compound, and the majority likewise also when he resolves it into its elements it: οὒς κῆρες φορέουσιν (Il. 8.528). Because it is customary for him to resolve the compound often. But never lengthening out the syllable in the dative, at the beginning it is compounded like πασι and πάντεσσι in παειμέλουσα (Od. 12.70). The compound is not only derived from from πάντεσσι, [for example] Ναυσικάα Ναυσίθοος, ἐγχεσίμοροι τειχεσιπλήτης. I placed it at the beginning, according to the [argument] from Epicharmos, and I compound it at the end like γυναικ’ ἄνδρεσσι ποθεινοί. Indeed if that is true it is clear that is is contrary to the rule. The κηρεσσιφορήτους must be read as a compound, but nevertheless the Aristarchean text is the authority according which logic we say it.
The texts of Aristarchus have it without the nu and it is: Ἕκτωρ δὲ πρώτοισι. Hector was hastening on at the front lines.
They shall thoroughly heal the wounds:
In the other [text] of Aristarchus it is ἕλκε ἀπαλθήσονται and there never is the superior form: ἕλκη ἀπαλθήσονται.

The sign is there because he [the poet] always says the Trojans with their allies are a smaller group. And the repetition with respect to those athetized lines, for example πολλεων ἐκ πολίων ἐχξέσπαλοι ἄνδρες (Il. 2.131) and the things written in Zenodotus μυρία δ’ ἐν πεδίω.
and indeed you being a bastard:

In Zenodotos, the line was not there. And it is athetized in Aristophanes because the family history is inappropriate and does not suit an exhortation but rather is a reproach and a dissuasion [from action].

The line is athetized because it is rather similar to the looking down on Patroclus. And what follows is athetized along with it because he wishes to stand there suddenly illuminated, so that Patroclus may be viewed suddenly. But there the stillness is stretched out for tranquility. It is not transmitted in Zenodotus's text. And Aristophanes also athetized it.
